item.title: Keynote at Information Retrieval for Climate Impact Workshop at SIGIR'24
item.description:
I gave a keynote at the Information Retrieval for Climate Impact Workshop at SIGIR'24 entitled Automating Systematic Reviews with Information Retrieval.

See the links above for more information and to download the slides.

item.title: Invited Workshop at Information Retrieval Meeting 2024
item.description:
I ran a workshop at the IQWiG Information Retrieval Meeting 2024 about using APIs for evidence identification.

More and more APIs (application programming interfaces) are used as programmatic interfaces for certain databases or data sets. This workshop explains what an API is and what knowledge is necessary to use them, for example:

  • what APIs are and how they work
  • offline versus online APIs
  • using APIs via Python

The focus of this workshop is to present use cases especially for frequently used APIs. This workshop explains what API use cases exist, what they are used for and how information specialists can use them in their daily workflows.

Above, you can find links to the supplementary material for the workshop which contains interactive notebooks that can be run in your browser. The notebooks let you edit and play with the code and data that are used in the workshop.

Finally, please find a list of related publications to this workshop below:

  • Can ChatGPT Write a Good Boolean Query for Systematic Review Literature Search?
    Shuai Wang, Harrisen Scells, Bevan Koopman, Guido Zuccon
    PDF Project
  • pybool_ir: A Toolkit for Domain-Specific Search Experiments
    Harrisen Scells, Martin Potthast
    PDF Code Project
  • searchrefiner: A Query Visualisation and Understanding Tool for Systematic Reviews
    Harrisen Scells, Guido Zuccon
    PDF Code Project

item.title: Invited Talk at TH Köln
item.description:
I gave a talk to the Information Retrieval Research Group at TH Köln entitled Efficiency and Energy in Neural Information Retrieval.

The talk can be downloaded here

The talk covered Green IR and a recent listwise neural IR model. The papers that were discussed in the talk are:

  • Reduce, Reuse, Recycle: Green Information Retrieval Research
    Harrisen Scells, Shengyao Zhuang, Guido Zuccon
    PDF Code
  • Set-Encoder: Permutation-Invariant Inter-Passage Attention for Listwise Passage Re-Ranking with Cross-Encoders
    Ferdinand Schlatt, Maik Fröbe, Harrisen Scells, Shengyao Zhuang, Bevan Koopman, Guido Zuccon, Benno Stein, Martin Potthast, Matthias Hagen
    Preprint Code

item.title: Invited Talk at the University Clinic Leipzig
item.description:
I gave a joint colloquium talk with Martin Potthast at the Institut für Laboratoriumsmedizin, Klinische Chemie und Molekulare Diagnostik (ILM) in Leipzig at the University Clinic entitled ChatGPT and Large Language Models for Medical Applications.

The talk can be downloaded here.

item.title: Invited Talk at University of Sheffield
item.description:
I gave a talk at the University of Sheffield Natural Language Processing Research Group entitled Query Automation for Systematic Reviews. This talk gave an overview of the papers accepted at SIGIR'23 this year.

Thanks to @hscells for today’s excellent @SheffieldNLP seminar “Query Automation for Systematic Reviews”

— Mark Stevenson (@drmarkstevenson) November 3, 2023

The slides are available for download here.

item.title: Attending the 2023 Heidelberg Laureate Forum
item.description:
I was selected to attend the 2023 Heidelberg Laureate Forum as a young researcher in the field of computer science. The event was held from September 24 - 29, 2023 in Heidelberg, Germany. Attendees included young researchers and laureates of the Abel Prize, ACM A.M. Turing Award, ACM Prize in Computing, Fields Medal, IMU Abacus Medal and Nevanlinna Prize.

The event was a unique mix of academic and cultural exploration, fostering interdisciplinary discussions and encouraging collaboration. Connecting with laureates and fellow young researchers, the forum left a lasting impact on me, providing inspiration and valuable connections.

I can absolutely recommend anyone interested to apply!

item.title: Invited Talk at Glasgow University IR Seminar
item.description:
I gave a talk at the Glasgow University IR Seminar entitled Query Automation for Systematic Reviews. This talk gave an overview of the papers accepted at SIGIR'23 this year.

An excellent talk by Harry Scells @hscells to end our 2022-2023 seminar series. Thanks to all our inspiring speakers this year, as well as to @hitarth_08 and @asash for coordinating the series. The new seminar series will start in September. Happy summer everyone! #IRTalk https://t.co/XVvrqXxE4m

— Glasgow IR Group (@ir_glasgow) July 11, 2023

The slides are available for download here.

item.title: Four papers accepted to SIGIR 2023
item.description:
This year, I was fortunate enough to be involved in four papers accepted at SIGIR (2 full papers, 1 resource paper, and 1 demo paper).

  • [resource] The Archive Query Log: Mining Millions of Search Result Pages of Hundreds of Search Engines from 25 Years of Web Archives
    • read paper
    • arxiv preprint
    • twitter thread
  • [full paper] Can ChatGPT Write a Good Boolean Query for Systematic Review Literature Search?
    • read paper
    • arxiv preprint
    • twitter thread
  • [demo] pybool_ir: A Toolkit for Domain-Specific Search Experiments
    • read paper
    • twitter thread
    • github
  • [full paper] Smooth Operators for Effective Systematic Review Queries
    • read paper
    • twitter thread

Thank you to all of my co-authors, for which this would not have been possible without you!

item.title: Invited Talk at Johannes Kepler University Linz
item.description:
I gave a talk at Johannes Kepler University Linz on Janurary 19, 2023 about my SIGIR'22 paper entitled Reduce, Reuse, Recycle: Green Information Retrieval Research. This talk gave an overview of the paper and discussed the current state of Green IR research, as well as some future directions.

The slides are available for download here.

Thank you very much Navid for the invitation!

item.title: Universities Australia – DAAD Joint Research Co-operation Scheme
item.description:
We are one of the 45 projects awarded funding under the Universities Australia – DAAD Joint Research Co-operation Scheme. This scheme facilitates the exchange of early career researchers in Australia and Germany from early 2023 until the end of 2024. The ielab and webis research groups will be hosting researchers from Australia and Germany for two months at a time. The following researchers will be visiting ielab and webis across the two years:

2023:

  • Shuai Wang from The University of Queensland, Australia.
  • Ferdinand Schlatt from Friedrich-Schiller-Universität Jena, Germany.

2024:

  • Xinyu Mao from The University of Queensland, Australia
  • Maik Fröbe from Friedrich-Schiller-Universität Jena, Germany.

The project involves the two groups working together to automate the searching and screening phases of systematic review creation.

For news about the project, publications, or other activities, please see the project website.

item.title: Network Meeting of the Alexander von Humboldt Foundation
item.description:
From November 9 - 11 2022, I’ll be attending the Network Meeting of the Alexander von Humboldt Foundation where I will give a talk about my AvH fellowship project entitled “Finding Answers to Complex Medical Questions”.

Click here to download the slides.

item.title: Schloss Dagstuhl Seminar
item.description:
From October 23 - 28 2022, I attended the Schloss Dagstuhl seminar entitled Towards a Unified Model of Scholarly Argumentation.

I volunteered to help edit the seminar report, which can be found here.

item.title: Attending the Analytics on Medical and Healthcare Data ADMA Workshop
item.description:
Awarded Best Presentation!

I attended the 2019 ADMA workshop entitled “Analytics on Medical and Healthcare Data” in Dalian, China. At the workshop, I gave a talk entitled “Improving Systematic Review Creation With Information Retrieval”, which won the best presentation award!

The slides of the talk can be downloaded here.
